column2: Check your components;The batteries are not included. You can buy them online or in larger electronics shops;Rechargeable batteries are excellent and good for the environment.;Tip: When soldering the components{
column3: } solder only one leg at a time. Then you can warm up the soldered joint again and correct the position.;Attention: All parts on the grass PCB are pushed{
column4: } from the side from which the golden blades of grass can be seen.;Caution: Always wear protective goggles. If you cut wires{

column2: First solder resistors R1-R3;Resistors have no direction and the values of R1-R3 are identical. It doesn't matter at which position you solder them;Cut off the excess wires.
Solder the switch SW1. You have to bend the solder flags downwards{
column3: } so that the solder flags touch the PCB.;First apply solder to one pad only{
column4: } put the solder aside. Then heat the spot again and slide the switch onto it from the side.

column2: Solder the switches SW2-SW4.; The tip{
column3: } to solder only one leg is very helpful here.; Then cut off the excess wire legs.

column2: Solder the potentiometers RV1-RV3.;Attention: Take special care{
column3: } that you insert the components from the right side.;Cut off the excess wires.

column2: Now take the flower and solder on the RGB-LED.; One pin is longer than all the others. This one has to go into the hole with the rectangular solder pad (not rounded corners).;Make sure{
column3: } that there are no solder bridges{

column2: Solder the straight pin headers to the flower;Put the short side through the flower from the back and solder the legs from the front;
Solder the flower stem to the long side of the pin header from the back;; Again{
column4: } that the labelling of the flower and also the labelling of the flower stem is on the back.

column2: Solder the straight pin headers to the flower; Push the short side through the flower from the back and solder the legs from the front.;
Solder the L-shaped pin header onto the flower stem. Put the pin header through the stem from the back and solder it from the front side.;Again{
column4: } that the pin header is not soldered crooked.

column2: Solder the flower stem onto the free holes on the grass board. The large potentiometers should be in front of the stem (see photo).
Shorten the cables of the battery holder to about 5cm.; Take a small piece of insulation off the wire ends and put some solder on it.
Put the wires from the bottom into the holes at the solder pads marked BT1 and (+); make sure{
column3: } that the red wire is soldered at the place with the (+); solder both wires.;Glue the motherboard to the battery holder with hot glue.;Put the caps on the potentiometers.

column2: You are done! With the push button on the back you can switch on your flower.;With the big potentiometers you can set the colours blue{
column3: } red and green. The small switches by the potentiometers can turn the colours completely on or off.;The small blue potentiometer on the back adjusts the overall brightness. Caution: If you turn it up too much{
column4: } individual colours will be switched off.
